web Django Project¶

This is a sample implementation that uses a number of X12 message parsing features.

This sample web site shows an approach to integrating X12 message processing with Django applications.

web.claims¶

This application uses an application-specific claim definition. The definition is entirely developed “by hand” and represents some specific use cases.

web.claims looks at hand-crafted Python classes for Claim 837 messages.

The application – as a whole – relies in the Django admin pages to do interactive work.

It defines two web services for loading and fetching.

Models¶

Definitions of persistent parts of an X12 message.

An X12 message instance is a recursive construction of Loops, sub-Loops and Segments. The leaf elements are always Segments. Segments contain, in turn, Composites and Elements.

There are a number of operations on a Message.

  • Unmarshalling (“parsing”). This is done by an instance of classes defined in the X12.parse package. The results of parsing is a Message Instance, built from classes in this module.
  • Marshalling. Each message can marshall itself into a block of text.
  • Persisting. Since the message instance is build from subclasses of django.db.models.Model, a call to save() persists the message.
  • Retrieving. The X12Message.objects manager can retreive any Message. Ordinary navigation will fetch Loops and Segments for that Message.

This must be changed in two ways to stop using DB-generated PK’s.

  • XXX - introduce an application-defined PK, at the Message level as the 1st part of all keys in a message structure.
  • XXX - introduce a 2nd part to the key generated by the Factory or the X12Message rather than the key created by the database.

Navigation¶

Look at X12.message for the XPath-like navigation model. This leads to a number of navgiation-oriented methods being folded into the class definitions.

Module Contents¶

Here are the class definitions within this module.

  • X12Message. The overall message – a collection of Loops.

  • X12Loop. A Loop is a collection of Segments and sub-Loops. In a SQL implementation, a Loop has an FK to the owning Message, as well as an FK to its immediate parent Loop. Top-level Loops, which belong directly to the Message have a NULL parent.

    • Some Loops are “wrappers”: a degenerate case that contain one Segment and no subLoops. This allows a Loop to contain a proper collection of Loops.
    • Some Loops are “explicit”: a properly named Loop which contains explicit subloops or wrapper loops around.

  • X12Segment. A Segment is a collection of Elements and Composites. Segments names are essentially a type name; there can be multiple instances within a single Loop, each with different semantics. In a SQL implementation, a Segment has an FK to the owning Message, as well as an FK to the immediate parent Loop.

  • X12Composite. A Composite is a collection of Elements. This is not actually implemented. It is merely attributes of a Segment.

  • X12Element. An atomic piece of data. These are identified positionally within a segment’s source text.

class web.claims.models.Benefit(*args, **kwargs)¶

The primary benefit for this claim.

Variables:
  • benefit – short name of the benefit
  • description – long description of the benefit.
class web.claims.models.ClaimGroup(*args, **kwargs)¶

A Group of claims. A group of claims has a status which collects groups together for different kinds of testing. A group also may have a dynamic processing state which reflects whether or not it has been sent to the claim processing system.

Variables:
  • name – name of the claim group. Base claims have a system-supplied default name. All other claim status have user-supplied names.
  • description – long description of this claim group.
  • status – the Group Status for this Claim Group.
  • owner – the User who created this Claim group.
  • created – the datetime of creation of this group definition.
  • modified – the datetime of modification of the group definition.
class web.claims.models.ClaimProperties(*args, **kwargs)¶

Selected properties of a claim. XXX - add source system.

Variables:
  • claimType – one of the defined L{ClaimType}s for this claim
  • secondaryCoverage – one of the defined L{SecondaryCoverage}s for this claim
  • location – one of the defined L{Location}s for this claim
  • typeOfService – one of the define L{TypeOfService}s for this claim
  • created – creation datetime for this property
  • modified – modification datetime for this property
class web.claims.models.ClaimType(*args, **kwargs)¶

The subtype of the 837 claim - Professional, Institutional, Dental.

Variables:
  • name – short name of the claim type (usually 1 character)
  • description – long name of the claim type
class web.claims.models.Factory¶

Create Django versions of the X12Message structures.

This object is used by an X12.parse to unmarshall message text and create Django objects.

static makeLoop(name, *structure)¶

Create a new X12Loop object.

Parameters:
  • name – name of this Loop
  • structure – the various sub-Loops and Segments of this Loop
Returns:

X12Loop instance
static makeMessage(name, *structure)¶

Create a new X12Message object.

Parameters:
  • name – name of this Message
  • structure – the various Loops of this Message
Returns:

X12Message instance
static makeSegment(segmentToken, compositeSep=':', segmentType=None)¶

Create a Segment from a SegmentToken and an Segment definition.

Another application can extend this data model to include Segment-type specific classes. That application will provide it’s own Factory, which is a subclass of this Factory, and will override this method to handle Segment-specific bindings.

Parameters:
  • segmentToken – An X12.parse.SegmentToken instance: a list-like collection of Element values. It turns out that a simple list of values may also work, if it does NOT have trailing empty items omitted. Real Segment Tokens can have trailing empty items omitted.
  • compositeSep – Composite internal separator from the ISA segment.
  • segmentType – An X12.parse.Segment instance, which defines the Elements and Composites of this X12Segment.
Returns:

X12Segment instance
class web.claims.models.GroupStatus(*args, **kwargs)¶

The status of a claim group. This defines what processing is allowed for claim group. Claims in a Base group, for instance, cannot be changed. Other status may have additional or different features.

Variables:
  • name – short status string
  • description – definition of the status
  • can_change – can claims in this group be changed?
class web.claims.models.Location(*args, **kwargs)¶

A named ‘location’ for a claim, usually geographic, but also possibly a line of business. Often this is a constraint on members or providers associated with a claim.

Variables:
  • name – short name of the location
  • description – long description of the location
class web.claims.models.SecondaryCoverage(*args, **kwargs)¶

Any secondary coverage in the claim.

Variables:
  • name – short name of the secondary coverage.
  • description – long name of the secondary coverage.
class web.claims.models.TestConstraints(*args, **kwargs)¶

The constraints that define how to modify this claim for unit test purposes.

Variables:
  • gender – allowed member genders.
  • age_low – minimum member age.
  • age_high – maximum member age.
class web.claims.models.TypeOfService(*args, **kwargs)¶

The type of service associated with this benefit. A benefit may have more than one type of service. The fullName is the “benefit / type of service” string.

XXX - needs validator: TOS is just unique for a given benefit, not globally unique.

Variables:
  • benefit – the associated benefit
  • typeOfService – short name of the type of service
  • description – long description of the type of service.
class web.claims.models.X12Loop(*args, **kwargs)¶

A Loop in an X12 message; it contains either subLoops or a Segment. A Loop which contains a Segment is a “Wrapper” and has no other information. A Loop which contains subloops is “Explicit” and has a name and could have other attributes.

Variables:
  • name – Name of this Loop
  • kind – Kind of loop: either ‘W’ for wrappers or ‘E’ for explicit
  • message – The Message to which this Loop belongs. This is set by addChild.
  • sequenceMessage – the sequence of this Loop within the overall Message. XXX - not fully supported.
  • parent – the parent Loop (or None) if this is a top loop in a message. This is set by addChild.
  • thePosition – the sequence of this Loop within the parent. This is set by addChild.
  • occurrence – the occurrence of this Loop type within a parent loop. This is set by the parser when handling multiple occurrences of loops or segments.
addChild(part)¶

Add either a Segment or a Loop to this Loop, setting overal message, parent and position of this child.

X12Segments can only be added under “Wrapper” Loops, where Loops can be added directly to Loops. Consequently, we need to delegate the work to the part. X12Segments will check for a wrapper; X12Loops will simply add themselves.

NOTE. Can’t add children unless the parent has a DB ID, which is assigned at SAVE time; hence, an initial save.

Parameters:part – the X12Segment or X12Loop to add to this Loop.
addToParent(parent)¶

Adds ourself to a parent Explicit Loop. An X12Segment will do this in a different way; a Segment must assure that it’s being added to a Wrapper loop. We’re an X12Loop, however, and can add ourself to Explicit loops, only.

Parameters:parent – the parent loop to which we’re adding ourself.
children()¶

Returns the list of meaningful children – supressing unnamed Wrapper Loops. :returns: list of X12Loops mingled with X12Segments in the correct order.

matches(test, name=None, pos=None)¶

The Xpath self axis

segmentWrapper()¶

Returns a Wrapper X12Loop for a Segment to add itself to. If we are a Wrapper loop, we return ourself. If we are an Explicit loop, we need to add a Wrapper and then return that Wrapper.

Returns:X12Loop of kind==”W”
segs()¶

Create a flat list of Segments under this Loop. This is the list of segments used for marshalling this message.

Returns:list of X12Segments.
class web.claims.models.X12Message(*arg, **kw)¶

An overall X12 Message: essentially a collection of Loops. To depict a unique message we can display unique internal identifiers tucked away inside the X12 structure, or the Database-assigned ID field, or an external identifier assigned at load time.

Two of these are relatively unpleasant.

It’s challenging to provide the internal identifiers for a message since a message is assembled in pieces. We don’t have the ISA segment or BHT segment until long after the message was initially created and assigned a internal ID.

The internal DB ID is assigned by the save() operation, making it difficult to build a message from the top down. We have to save the empty X12Message row in order to correctly associate X12Loops with it. Then we have to save the X12Loops to correctly associate X12Segment instances.

Therefore, we require a unique message ID to be supplied at load time. This is the physical PK – a DB defined PK is not used. Each Loop gets a PK generated by our application, not a DB-defined PK, so that we can build an entire message structure before deciding to persist it.

Variables:
  • name – Name of this message. XXX - replace with ID as PK.
  • properties – Claim Properties for this message.
addChild(aLoop)¶

Add a loop to this Message.

Parameters:aLoop – an X12Loop instance.
getBHTid()¶

Try to get ID information from the BHT segment. BHT03 might be a unique ID.

getISAid()¶

Try to get ID information from the ISA segment. ISA09 + ISA10 + ISA13 provide date, time and an ID.

marshall(segSep='~', eltSep='*')¶

Marshall this message into an X12 string.

Parameters:
  • segSep – (optional) Segment Terminator, usually ~
  • eltSep – (optional) Element Separator, usually *
Returns:

String with this X12 message marshalled
matches(test, name=None, pos=None)¶

The Xpath self axis

segs()¶

Create the flat list of Segments under this Message.

Returns:list of X12Segment instances.
class web.claims.models.X12Segment(*arg, **kw)¶

A generic segment in an X12 message, created by a parser from a segmentToken. Type-specific Segments will have a 1:1 relationship with this Segment, but will have detailed Element definitions instead of this generic definition.

To make this generic version work, we store the entire X12.parse.SegmentToken as a big-ole block of text in the database. Methods within this object unpack the text block to access individual Elements. Further, if a change is made, the text block is repacked from the element list.

We could use a Django Custom Field definition for this. It would make the conversion back and forth between list and database-friendly String transparent.

Variables:
  • elements – internal list of elements derived from self.text.
  • segType – internal reference to X12.parse.Segment definition.
  • name – Name of this Segment
  • text – SegmentToken text for this segment.
  • message – top-most Message which contains this Segment
  • sequence – Message sequence of this Segment within the overall Message.
  • loop – parent Loop for this Segment. Must be a Wrapper kind of Loop.
  • occurrence – Occurrence of this segment type within the parent Loop.
addToParent(parentLoop)¶

X12Segment adding itself to a parent Wrapper Loop. Or – if the parent is Explicit – adding the needed Wrapper. We ask the parent for the “segmentWrapper”: if the parent is a Wrapper, that’s what is returned; if the parent is Explicit, the parent inserts the necessary wrapper and returns the wrapper.

Parameters:parentLoop – parent X12Loop to which we must add ourself.
bind(segment)¶

Bind an X12.parse.Segment to this data.

Parameters:segment – An X12.parse.Segment instance
getByName(name)¶

Get the value of an Element by the element name. This only works if this X12Segment is bound to an X12.parse.Segment.

Parameters:name – name of the Element
Returns:string value of the Element.
getByPos(position)¶

Get the value of an Element by the position number.

Parameters:position – position of the Element
Returns:string value of the Element.
marshall(eltSep='*')¶

Marshalls this Segment’s elements as a text string.

Returns:String value of this Segment.
matches(test, name=None, pos=None)¶

The Xpath self axis

positionOf(name)¶

Returns the position of a named Element. This only works if this X12Segment is bound to an X12.parse.Segment.

Parameters:name – Element name
Returns:numberic position of this Element.
segs()¶

Returns this Segment in a list, consistent with X12Loop and X12Message.

setByPos(position, value)¶

Set the value of an Element by the position number. This updates the text attribute of the persistent object.

Parameters:
  • position – position of the Element
  • value – String value to replace

Views¶

Claims view functions.

class web.claims.views.Loader(parser)¶

Load generic claims. Loading a claim, creates the associated properties, test constraints, and a default group that claims are loaded to.

load(claim, claimID, properties, constraints)¶

Load a Claim, conforming it with ClaimProperties and TestConstraints. A generic parser defined in X12.parse is tried to parse the message. If the message can be parsed, the resulting object is persisted in the database, associated with the given properties and constraints.

Note that the properties and constraints are conformed into several different dimensions. If there are unique values in the attributes, new rows will be created in the dimension tables. If this is not intended, there are two choices:

  • Validate the constraints against the dimensions outside this service.
  • Report the new values in the dimension to the users and have them reassign the dimension values. This seems like needless work, but it turns out to be simpler because it gets fewer rejections and helps users discover and respond to changes in the baseline claim-processing system.

XXX - get actual user as an argument – it’s originally in the request.

Parameters:
  • claim – source text for a generic X12 claim.
  • claimID – a unique identifier for this claim.
  • properties – dictionary of properties attributes, used by _conformProperties()
  • constraints – dictionary of automod constrain attributes, used by _conformConstraints()
Returns:

the Claim loaded or an exception
web.claims.views.fetch(request, claim_id)¶

GET request with claim_id.

Fetch a given claim from the database. Marshall it as an X12 message.

Parameters:claimID – the claim identifier provided when the claim was loaded.
Returns:status tuple ( status, message )
web.claims.views.load(*args, **kwargs)¶

POST request with claim, claim_id, properties, constraints.

The POST request has four parameters:

Claim :is the X12-encoded message.
Claim_id :is the user-assigned unique ID for this claim.
Properties :is a JSON-encoded Properties object for this claim.
Constraints :is a JSON-encoded TestConstraint object for this claim.

URLs¶

claims.urls

There two RESTful URL’s here. They work in JSON notation.

  • load/ is the load service. This requires a number of parameters. See web.claims.views.load().
  • claim_id/ is the fetch service. See web.claims.views.fetch().

Parse¶

web.claims_837¶

This application uses an 837 parser built by tools.convertPyX12. This conversion creates the Django models so that more generic claims processing can be performed.

web.claims_837 is a web application for looking at Claim 837 messages.

The web.claims_837.models module defines the X12 message instance classes based on parsed definitions built by the tools.convertPyX12.

Models¶

Generated by make837.py on 2008-02-12 14:41:11.161000

Views¶

Claims_837 views.

class web.claims_837.views.Loader¶

Load claims_837-specific claim segments. Loading a claim, creates the associated properties, automod constraints, and a default group that claims are loaded to.

load(claim, claimID, properties, constraints)¶

Load a Claim, conforming it with ClaimProperties. The various parsers (parse_837p, parse_837i, parse_837d) defined in L{web.claims_837.parse} are tried to see which can successfully parse the message. If the message can be parsed, the resulting object is persisted in the database, associated with the given properties.

Note that the properties are conformed into several different dimensions. If there are unique values in the attributes, new rows will be created in the dimension tables.

Parameters:
  • claim – source text for an 837 claim.
  • claimID – a unique identifier for this claim.
  • properties – dictionary of properties attributes, used by _conformProperties
Returns:

the Claim loaded or an exception
web.claims_837.views.fetch(request, claim_id)¶

GET request with claim_id. Fetch a given claim from the database. Marshall it as an X12 message.

Parameters:claimID – the claim identifier provided when the claim was loaded.
Returns:status tuple ( status, message )
web.claims_837.views.load(*args, **kwargs)¶

POST request with claim, claim_id, properties. Use the “claims_837” model.

Extract¶

Extract Claims Messages.

Synopsis¶

extract.py description.csv...

Description¶

Options¶

Environment Variables¶

DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE is the Django Settings Module that defines the database and other runtime environment parameters.

Fetch¶

Batch Fetch Claims Messages.

Synopsis¶

fetch.py description.csv...

Description¶

Reads the CSV-format descriptions, either from stdin or files supplied as command-line arguments. Each file contains rows which provide the claim identifiers. Other attributes are silently ignored.

This program calls the claim fetch service, and writes a log of success and failures.

Options¶

*description.csv`* a CSV-format files which identifies claims to fetch. If omitted, :file:`stdin is read.

Environment Variables¶

DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE is the Django Settings Module that defines the database and other runtime environment parameters.

CSV FILE FORMAT¶

The claim description file has the following format. Either the columns MUST be in the following order, or the first row MUST have these column titles.

  • CLAIM-ID. This is the unique claim ID which will be assigned.

Other columns are permitted in this file. They are ignored. For example, the following additional column is often used.

  • GWID This is the HIPAA Gateway Transaction ID for the claim, used to retrieve it from FACETS.

Load¶

Batch Load Claims Messages associated with Classification plus Automod Parameters.

Synopsis¶

load.py description.csv...

Description¶

Reads the CSV-format descriptions, either from stdin or files supplied as command-line arguments. Each file contains rows which provide three separate things:

  • name of a file with claim(s) to parse (or the claim itself),
  • classification parameters for the claims,
  • automod constraints for the claims [XXX this may be derivable from the claim].

This program calls the claim load service, and writes a log of success and failures.

Before this program can be run, an extract must be used to get the X12N claims out of the source application’s HIPAA gateway. The extract process uses a request .csv file, and writes the X12N files, plus the description .csv file.

The typical use case for this loader is as follows:

claimExtract request.csv | load.py

Options¶

*description.csv`* a CSV-format files which identifies claims to load. If omitted, :file:`stdin is read.

Environment Variables¶

DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE is the Django Settings Module that defines the database and other runtime environment parameters.

CSV FILE FORMAT¶

The claim description file has the following format. Either the columns MUST be in the following order, or the first row MUST have these column titles.

  • CLAIM-ID. This is the unique claim ID which will be assigned.
  • BENEFIT The Benefit ID to assign to this claim. This is checked against the TOS/Benefit list.
  • TYPE-OF-SERVICE The Type of Service ID to assign to this claim. This is checked against the TOS/Benefit list.
  • LOCATION The codes are ALB, BUF, CE and CW. Descriptions are Albany, Buffalo, Central NY West, and Central NY East.
  • TYPE The codes are I, P, O or D. Descriptions are In-Patient, Professional, Out-Patient and Dental.
  • SECONDARY The codes are M and R. Descriptions are Medicare and Regular.
  • GENDER This is used to define an automod constraint. Codes are M, F and U.
  • AGE-FROM This is used to define an automod constraint.
  • AGE-TO This is used to define an automod constraint.
  • CLAIM-FILE If present, this is the file that contains the X12 message for this claim. If omitted, the CLAIM-TEXT column must be used to provide the actual X12N message.
  • CLAIM-TEXT If present, this is the text of the X12 message for this claim. If omitted, the CLAIM-FILE column must be used to provide the name of a file with the actual X12N message.

Other columns are permitted in this file. They are ignored. For example, the following additional column is often used.

  • GWID This is the HIPAA Gateway Transaction ID for the claim, used to retrieve it from FACETS.
web.claims_837.load.loadClaimAndDescription(csvFile)¶

Load a set of claims provided in a CSV-format file. Each row of the CSV file describes one (rarely multiple) claim. It provides a complete set of Properties and AutomodConstraints for the claim.

Parameters:csvFile – an open file (or file-like object) that can be used by csv.DictReader to get claims, properties and constraints.
web.claims_837.load.loadClaims(claimIter, claimId, properties=None, constraints=None)¶

Load a collection of claims, all of which have a common set of properties and automod constraints.

Parameters:
  • claimIter – An iterator over some claims, a list or a file will work. Often an X12.file is used because it streamlines the file reading.
  • claimId – The base claim id. If multiple claims are loaded, then claims after the first will have “-n” appended to the claim id string.
  • properties – A dict with Claim Properties.
  • constraints – A dict with Automod constraints.

URLs¶

claims_837.urls

There two RESTful URL’s here. They work in JSON notation.

  • load/ is the load service. This requires a number of parameters. See web.claims_837.views.load().
  • claim_id/ is the fetch service. See web.claims_837.views.fetch().

web.make837¶

Converts the 837 claim message definitions into Python parsers and Django ORM structures to define the web.claims_837.models classes.

Build 837 parsers and 837 Segment definitions from XML Configuration.

Synopsis¶

make837.py -p python -d django -b baseDir name=source...

Description¶

Reads the PyX12 source files (in .XML) and writes a Python parser module for unmarshalling messages as well as a Django model for persisting the message instances.

Prior to this step you must initialize the application directory structure with manage.py startapp newApp.

After this step, you must update settings.py to include the new application.

Then you must sync the database with the following command before you can start using the parser, factory and Django persistent class definitions you’ve created.

manage.py syncdb --pythonpath=".."

Options¶

-p python writes the Python module for unmarshalling the given messages.

-d django writes two Django modules for persisting the given message instances.
This will be django/models.py and django/admin.py.

-b baseDir is the base directory for the various source files.

name=source a list of parser names and message definitions. The name is the Python variable name; the source is the PyX12 XML source file.

Notes¶

An X12 parser is defined to use a Factory object to emit message instance objects. This Factory object is a run-time binding between a parser and some message instance module. Generic message instance modules include X12.message and web.claims.models.

This application builds a specific message instance module, with specific message types. In order for an X12.parse module to make use of the Django message instance module, a Factory is required to instantiate the Django objects as well as the generic X12Segment object defined in web.claims.models.

class web.make837.ApplicationBuilder(baseDir=None)¶

Build the core parser and message persistence modules for an application.

Generally, given a base directly, we’ll load a number of XML files which will define X12N message parsers. We have to emit a Python source module for each individual message type, since they have unique compliance rules.

After seeing all of those XML files, we’ll also know the various segments defined and can emit a peristence model for the unique kinds of segments.

Note that the Django Visitor accumulates the various definitions. Only the last output from the Django Visitor is particularly useful.

getDjangoAdmin(appname='claims_837')¶

Emit the Django Admin code built so far.

getDjangoModel()¶

Emit the Django model code built so far.

getParser¶

Return the current message’s parser object.

getPython(name)¶

Return Python source for the current message.

load(xmlDef)¶

Load another message definition. This will also accumulate Django Segment definitions.
